questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?

options.option_text: JavaScript is a low level programming language.
The “const” keyword can be used to declare objects with block level scope.
Int, char are some primitive data types in the JavaScript language.
The JavaScript language supports both the first order and higher orderfunctions.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: A web application must implement token based authentication to make theapplication secure.
The JAMStack approach separates out the frontend from the backend, andthey both can be updated/modified independently without affecting the other.
It is recommended to avoid the usage of verbs in the API data URLs.
The idea behind bringing an API is to implement caching.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?

options.option_text: A Celery system can only use Redis as the message broker.
A Celery system may consist of a number of batch jobs.
A Celery system needs worker(s) to execute tasks.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?

options.option_text: The term “polling” generally refers to short polling.
Webhooks are used for 1 way communication, unlike web sockets.
In polling, the connection to the server is kept open, until the data is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?

options.option_text: Cookies are stored on the server.
Cookies are stored on the browser.
Browser sends the cookies to the origin server automatically in general.
Client has to include cookies manually with the request, in general.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?

options.option_text: It is a protocol to allow access to resources, hosted on a different server, onbehalf of a user.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?
question_texts: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?

options.option_text: Closure is the state of the outer function.
Closure is the state of a variable.
Closure is a function along with its lexical environment or surrounding state.
Closures are created every time a function is created in JavaScript.

The CORS headers are generally prefixed with the value “Access-Control-Allow”.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: The server sent events is a mechanism for a server to push events, and it mustrequire service workers on the client to function properly.
In general, a webhook is meant to pull message(s) from an application.
The usage of a message broker over “point-to-point” communication makesthe application scalable.
There is no difference between webhooks and short polling.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)

options.option_text: The approach 1 will wait for a user input before dispatching the task to thecelery system.
The approach 2 will dispatch the task to the celery system after waiting for 10seconds, and start the execution, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 2 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, butstart the execution after waiting for 10 seconds, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 1 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, andstart the execution, assuming a worker is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?

options.option_text: In general, an application should have separate Vuex stores for all thecomponents.
A path defined in the routes array in Vue router can consist of a number ofchildren paths.
The wildcard (*) should be put at the top of the routes array in the Vue router,so that it matches with all the paths, which are not implemented.
A Vuex store must be used with all Vue applications.

options.option_text: The credentials property of the Request interface allows the user agent tosend or receive cookies in cross-origin requests.
The value “omit” of “credentials” will force the browser not to send cookies withthe request.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialseven in cross-origin requests.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialsonly for same origin requests.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?

options.option_text: The local storage is a browser based persistent storage.
Cookies are preferred over session or local storage, when the data needs to besent with every request.
The cookies can be set from the server as well as using javascript on the client.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** essential for the exam, along with **key equations** (where applicable) and **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ### **Core Topics & Concepts Summary** #### **1. JavaScript Fundamentals** - **Primitive Data Types**: `number`, `string`, `boolean`, `null`, `undefined`, `symbol`, `BigInt`. *Note*: `int`/`char` are **not** primitive in JS (Q2). - **`const` vs `let`**: - `const`: Block-scoped, cannot be reassigned (but objects/arrays can be mutated). - `let`: Block-scoped, can be reassigned. - **First-Order vs Higher-Order Functions**: - **First-order**: Treated as variables (passed as args, returned from functions). - **Higher-order**: Accepts/returns functions (e.g., `map`, `filter`). - **Closures**: - A function + its lexical environment (surrounding state). - Created every time a function is defined (Q8). - Example: ```javascript function outer() { let x = 10; return function inner() { console.log(x); }; // Closure } ``` - **Promises & Async/Await**: - **Promise States**: `pending` → `fulfilled` (resolved) or `rejected`. - **`async/await`**: Syntactic sugar for promises. `await` pauses execution until the promise settles. - **Error Handling**: Use `.catch()` or `try/catch` with `await`. - Example (Q25, Q28, Q29): ```javascript new Promise((resolve, reject) => { if (success) resolve(value); else reject(error); }) .then(d => console.log(d)) .catch(e => console.log(e)) .finally(() => console.log("Done")); ``` - **Arrow Functions vs Regular Functions**: - Arrow functions inherit `this` from the surrounding scope (lexical `this`). - Regular functions have their own `this` (dynamic, depends on how called). - Example (Q27): ```javascript const obj = { propA: 10, func: () => console.log(this.propA) // `this` is global/window (undefined in strict mode) }; ``` --- #### **2. Modern Web Development** - **JAMStack**: - **Decoupled Architecture**: Frontend (static) + Backend (APIs) can be updated independently (Q3). - **No Token Requirement**: Token-based auth is optional (not mandatory for security). - **API Design**: - **RESTful URLs**: Avoid verbs (use nouns, e.g., `/users` instead of `/getUsers`). - **Caching**: Not the primary purpose of APIs (Q3). - **Authentication/Authorization**: - **OAuth**: - **Authorization protocol** (not authentication). - Allows third-party access to resources on behalf of a user (Q7). - **CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)**: - **Protection**: Anti-CSRF tokens must be sent with requests (Q11). - **Flask**: Does **not** enforce CSRF protection by default. - **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**: - **Headers**: Prefixed with `Access-Control-Allow-*` (e.g., `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`). - **Purpose**: Secure web apps from external origins (Q11). - **Cookies vs Local/Session Storage**: | Feature | Cookies | Local Storage | Session Storage | |-----------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|------------------------| | **Storage Location** | Browser + Server | Browser (client-side) | Browser (client-side) | | **Persistence** | Configurable (expire) | Persistent | Session-only | | **Capacity** | ~4KB | ~5MB | ~5MB | | **Sent with Requests**| Yes (automatically) | No | No | - **Use Cases**: - Cookies: Authentication, tracking (sent with every request). - Local Storage: Persistent client-side data (e.g., user preferences). - Session Storage: Temporary data (cleared when tab closes) (Q33). --- #### **3. Vue.js** - **Core Concepts**: - **Reactivity**: Data-driven DOM updates (e.g., `v-model`, `v-bind`). - **Directives**: - `v-if`/`v-show`: Conditional rendering. - `v-for`: Looping. - `v-bind`: Dynamic attributes (e.g., `:class`). - `v-on`: Event handling (e.g., `@click`). - **Lifecycle Hooks**: `created`, `mounted`, `updated`, `destroyed`. - **Components**: - **Props**: Pass data from parent to child. - **Slots**: Inject content into components. - **Dynamic Components**: ``. - **Class/Style Binding**: - **Object Syntax**: `:class="{ 'classA': isActive, 'classB': isError }"` (Q20). - **Array Syntax**: `:class="[classA, { classB: isActive }]"`. - **Computed Properties vs Methods**: - **Computed**: Cached, reactive (use for derived data). - **Methods**: Re-run on every render (use for event handlers). - **Vue Router**: - **Dynamic Routes**: `:id` in paths (e.g., `/user/:id`). - **Nested Routes**: Children routes under a parent. - **Navigation**: `this.$router.push({ name: 'routeName', params: {...} })` (Q17, Q18). - **Wildcard (`*`)**: Must be **last** in routes array (matches unmatched paths) (Q23). - **Vuex (State Management)**: - **Core Concepts**: `state`, `getters`, `mutations`, `actions`, `modules`. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state updates (Q26). - **Actions**: Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - **Best Practices**: - Single store for the entire app (not per component) (Q23). - Avoid direct state mutations outside mutations. - **Event Handling**: - **Modifiers**: `.prevent`, `.stop`, `.once`. - **Custom Events**: `$emit` in child, `@custom-event` in parent. - **Forms & `v-model`**: - Two-way binding for form inputs (Q10, Q16). - **Modifiers**: `.lazy`, `.number`, `.trim`. - **Conditional Rendering**: - `v-if` vs `v-show`: `v-if` removes DOM element; `v-show` toggles `display: none`. --- #### **4. Asynchronous Communication** - **Polling vs Webhooks vs WebSockets**: | Mechanism | Direction | Connection | Use Case | |----------------|-----------------|-------------------|------------------------------| | **Polling** | Client → Server | Short-lived | Periodic checks (e.g., emails) | | **Webhooks** | Server → Client | HTTP callback | Real-time notifications (e.g., GitHub) | | **WebSockets** | Bidirectional | Persistent | Chat apps, live updates | - **Short Polling**: Client requests data at intervals. - **Long Polling**: Server holds request until data is available. - **Webhooks**: Server pushes data to a client URL (one-way) (Q5, Q21). - **Server-Sent Events (SSE)**: - Server pushes events to client over HTTP (no service workers required) (Q21). - **Message Brokers (Celery + Redis)**: - **Celery**: Distributed task queue (supports Redis, RabbitMQ, etc.). - **Redis**: Can act as a message broker or cache. - **Task Execution**: - `task.delay()`: Immediate dispatch. - `task.apply_async(countdown=N)`: Dispatch after `N` seconds (Q4, Q22). - **Components**: - **Broker**: Manages task queue (e.g., Redis). - **Workers**: Execute tasks. - **Beat**: Scheduler for periodic tasks. --- #### **5. Fetch API & HTTP** - **Credentials in Fetch**: - `credentials: 'include'`: Send cookies in cross-origin requests. - `credentials: 'omit'`: Exclude cookies. - `credentials: 'same-origin'`: Default (send cookies for same origin only) (Q24). - **Request Methods**: - `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`, `PATCH`, `OPTIONS` (preflight for CORS). - **Headers**: - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`: Specifies allowed origins. - `Content-Type`: `application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, etc. --- #### **6. Security** - **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**: - **Preflight Request**: `OPTIONS` request to check if actual request is safe. - **Headers**: - `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`: `*` or specific origin. - `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`: Allowed HTTP methods. - **CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)**: - **Attack**: Tricks user into submitting a malicious request. - **Mitigation**: - Anti-CSRF tokens (sent with forms/requests). - SameSite cookies. - **OAuth 2.0**: - **Flows**: Authorization Code, Implicit, Client Credentials, PKCE. - **Roles**: Resource Owner, Client, Authorization Server, Resource Server. --- #### **7. Backend & Task Queues** - **Celery**: - **Task States**: `PENDING`, `STARTED`, `SUCCESS`, `FAILURE`, `RETRIED`. - **Retries**: Configure with `max_retries` and `default_retry_delay`. - **Periodic Tasks**: Use `Celery Beat`. - **Redis**: - **Data Structures**: Strings, Lists, Sets, Hashes, Sorted Sets. - **Use Cases**: Caching, session storage, message broker. --- #### **8. Vue.js Practical Examples** - **Dynamic Class Binding (Q12, Q13)**: ```html
...
``` ```javascript computed: { isEven() { return this.run % 2 === 0; } } ``` - **Vue Router (Q17, Q18)**: - **Dynamic Segments**: `/user/:id` → Access via `this.$route.params.id`. - **Named Routes**: `this.$router.push({ name: 'user', params: { id: 1 } })`. - **Vuex Store (Q26)**: ```javascript mutations: { updateFinal(state, { minExperience, maxAge }) { state.shortlisted = state.candidates.filter(c => c.experience >= minExperience && c.age < maxAge ); } }, actions: { sendTask({ commit }) { commit('updateFinal', { minExperience: 3, maxAge: 30 }); } } ``` - **Component Communication**: - **Parent → Child**: Props. - **Child → Parent**: `$emit` + `@event`. - **Non Parent-Child**: Event Bus or Vuex. --- ### **Key Equations/Code Snippets** #### **JavaScript** 1. **Closure Example**: ```javascript function outer() { let x = 10; return function inner() { console.log(x); }; // x is preserved } const closure = outer(); closure(); // Output: 10 ``` 2. **Promise Chaining (Q25)**: ```javascript new Promise((resolve, reject) => { let a = 2 * 4 || 0 / 4; // a = 8 (2*4 is truthy) let b = 3 * 4 && 0 / 4; // b = 0 (0/4 is falsy) if (a > b) resolve(a); else reject(b); }) .then(d => console.log("Passed:", d)) .catch(e => console.log("Failed:", e)); // Output: Failed: 0 ``` 3. **Arrow Function `this` (Q27)**: ```javascript const obj1 = { propA: 20 }; const obj2 = { propA: 30, propB: function() { let func = () => console.log(this.propA); // `this` is obj1 (lexical) func.call(obj1); // Output: 20 } }; obj2.propB.call(obj1); ``` #### **Vue.js** 1. **Computed Property (Q12)**: ```javascript computed: { changeStrike() { return this.run % 2 === 0; // Toggles class based on `run` } } ``` 2. **Vuex Mutation (Q26)**: ```javascript mutations: { updateFinal(state, { minExperience, maxAge }) { state.shortlisted = state.candidates.filter(c => c.experience >= minExperience && c.age < maxAge ); } } ``` 3. **Dynamic Class Binding (Q20)**: ```html
``` #### **Celery Tasks (Q22)** ```python # Approach 1: Immediate execution send_email.delay() # Approach 2: Delayed execution (10 seconds) send_email.apply_async(countdown=10) ``` --- ### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** #### **1. JavaScript Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[JavaScript] --> B[Primitive Types] A --> C[Functions] C --> C1[First-Order Functions] C --> C2[Higher-Order Functions] A --> D[Closures] D --> D1[Lexical Environment] A --> E[Asynchronous] E --> E1[Promises] E --> E2[Async/Await] E --> E3[Event Loop] ``` #### **2. Vue.js Ecosystem** ```mermaid graph TD A[Vue.js] --> B[Core] B --> B1[Reactivity] B --> B2[Directives] B --> B3[Lifecycle Hooks] A --> C[Components] C --> C1[Props] C --> C2[Slots] C --> C3[Dynamic Components] A --> D[State Management] D --> D1[Vuex] D1 --> D1a[State] D1 --> D1b[Getters] D1 --> D1c[Mutations] D1 --> D1d[Actions] A --> E[Routing] E --> E1[Vue Router] E1 --> E1a[Dynamic Routes] E1 --> E1b[Nested Routes] ``` #### **3. Asynchronous Communication** ```mermaid graph TD A[Asynchronous Communication] --> B[Polling] B --> B1[Short Polling] B --> B2[Long Polling] A --> C[Webhooks] C --> C1[HTTP Callbacks] A --> D[WebSockets] D --> D1[Bidirectional] A --> E[Server-Sent Events] E --> E1[Unidirectional] A --> F[Message Brokers] F --> F1[Celery] F --> F2[Redis] ``` #### **4. Security Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Security] --> B[CORS] B --> B1[Access-Control-Allow-Origin] B --> B2[Preflight Requests] A --> C[CSRF] C --> C1[Anti-CSRF Tokens] C --> C2[SameSite Cookies] A --> D[OAuth] D --> D1[Authorization] D --> D2[Flows: Authorization Code, Implicit] ``` #### **5. Vuex Workflow** ```mermaid graph LR A[Component] -->|Dispatch| B[Action] B -->|Commit| C[Mutation] C -->|Update| D[State] D -->|Render| A D -->|Getters| E[Derived State] ``` --- ### **Exam Tips** 1. **JavaScript**: - Focus on closures, `this` binding, and promise/async-await behavior. - Understand the difference between `==` and `===`, truthy/falsy values. 2. **Vue.js**: - Know the lifecycle hooks and when to use `computed` vs `methods`. - Practice `v-bind`, `v-model`, and dynamic components. - Understand Vuex mutations vs actions (synchronous vs asynchronous). 3. **Web Concepts**: - Differentiate between polling, webhooks, and WebSockets. - Know CORS headers and CSRF protection mechanisms. 4. **Celery/Redis**: - Understand task queues, delayed execution, and workers. 5. **Security**: - Remember that cookies are sent automatically with requests (unlike localStorage). - OAuth is for authorization, not authentication.
